items.item: Vapor units with Interlock system
assets/global/img/B1110/vapor_funktionsskizze.jpg

The Interlock system holds and connects the anesthetic agent vaporizers. Vaporizers are designed to add a controlled amount of anesthetic agent to the fresh gas flow.
Up to two vaporizers can be mounted on the Primus Anesthesia Workstation.
Dräger Vapor® 2000 is an unheated, calibrated anesthetic vaporizer for the enrichment of dry, fresh medical gas in anesthesia delivery systems with accurately-controlled concentrations of vapour from liquid anesthetic agents. The concentration delivered is, for the most part, not influenced by operating and ambient conditions, such as temperature, gas flow and ventilation pressure.
D-Vapor – heated, calibrated anesthetic vaporizer for the enrichment of dry, fresh medical gas with vapour of the anesthetic agent Desflurane (Suprane) in concentrations of 2 to 18 vol.% in anesthesia delivery systems.
Vapor Units with Auto Exclusion system
assets/global/img/B1110/D-12789-2009_1000.jpg

The Dräger Auto Exclusion vaporizer comfort mounting system is a new generation vaporizer interface for all Vapor 2000 and D-Vapor that will help simplify your routine, increase your efficiency and flexibility and avoid user error. The Auto Exclusion quick mount system effectively eliminates the possibility of activating more than one vaporizer at a time. Once one vaporizer is turned on, the other is automatically blocked. This translates to enhanced patient safety and reduced likelihood of significant user error.
assets/global/img/B1110/D-12806-2009.jpg
Downward Compatibility and Functionality
You can continue to use Dräger vaporizers with Auto Exclusion plug-in adapter with the standard Dräger Interlock 2 system.
Vapor Units with Auto Exclusion system are not available in all countries.

Endotracheal suction systems are used to extract secretion from the airways, in particular in the case of patients who are ventilated.
The driving gas is AIR, AIR/O2, or VAC (vacuum), depending on the type of bronchial aspirator.
The following device types are currently available: – Bronchial aspirator with ejector – Bronchial aspirator with vacuum
assets/global/img/B1120/B1120.jpg
assets/global/img/B1130/D-12348-2009.jpg
Safe Protection against Water and Bacteria

The WaterLock 2 is a single use water trap for separating water from sample gas. It protects the gas measurement monitor against water, bacteria and viruses. Dräger has designed its Water Lock 2 with two hydrophobic membranes instead of one. This twin membrane protection system keeps condensation out of the sampling gas and the purge gas. Even if the sample line falls into the secretion aspiration system e. g. during a change of patients, no water will get into the gas measurement system. Two self sealing filter elements enhance safety: they will turn blue if occluded.
Safe and simple Handling
All you have to do to empty the WaterLock 2 is simply remove it from holder, stick a syringe in the connector and suck out the water.
assets/global/img/B1130/waterfall.jpg
Placing the WaterLock 2 adapter
assets/global/img/B1130/Animation_1.swf
Mounting and replacing of the WaterLock 2
Replacing the water trap
When the maximum service life of 4 weeks is reached.
If there is an error message on the monitor or the Anesthesia workstation.
If emptying does not rectify the error message of the monitor or the Anesthesia workstation.
If it is severely soiled.
If the swelling seals in the connections turn blue.
assets/global/img/B1130/Animation_2.swf

subsubsite.label: O2-Flush and Safety O2
subsubsite.title: O2-Flush and Safety O2
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: For flushing and rapidly filling the breathing system and breathing bag with O2 while bypassing the vaporizer. The O2 flush delivers at least a stable flow of 35 l/min.

The O2 emergency delivery "Safety O2" is a safety function that works in Stand-by and even when the Primus is switched off. By pressing the safety knob and adjusting a required O2 flow (0-12 l/min) the patient can be supported with Oxygen. The O2 flow goes through the vaporizers which allows anesthetic agent dosing. Oxygen delivery also functions in the unlikely case of a mixer failure.

items.item: assets/global/img/B1150/kombiniertes-bild.jpg
1. Drägersorb®

Principle of operation: Contains a cannister of soda lime. It is used to absorb the patient's exhaled carbon dioxide. During the chemical reaction that takes place, water and heat are produced which warms and humidifies the gases as they pass through the soda lime.
Drägersorb® 800 Plus, 5 l (176 fl oz.) Soda lime in pellet form with color indicator from white to violet. For the absorption of carbon dioxide (CO2) from breathing gas in inhalation Anesthesia machines with rebreathing system.
Drägersorb® Free, 5 l (176 fl oz.) Soda lime in pellet form with color indicator from white to violet. For the absorption of carbon dioxide (CO2) from breathing gas in inhalation Anesthesia machines with rebreathing system. In use with Sevoflurane, Drägersorb Free prevents generation of Compound A and Carbon Monoxide.
2. Drägersorb® CLIC
assets/global/img/B1150/B1150.jpg

Drägersorb® CLIC, 1.2 l (42.2 fl oz.) The Drägersorb CLIC disposable absorber for Dräger Anesthesia machines is attached to the existing absorber holder by means of an adapter. A quick, clean, easy-to-use disposable solution. Drägersorb CLIC is filled with Drägersorb 800 Plus, 1.2 l or 1.2L CLIC absorber Free
The disposable absorber can be replaced during operation. The valve in the mounting ensures that the breathing system remains tightly sealed when the absorber is removed.

subsubsite.label: Compact Breathing System
subsubsite.title: Compact Breathing System
subsubsite.copy: The Compact Breathing System delivers the intended (set) inspired gas mixture to the patient and permits easy removal of waste exhaled gases. As the set inspired gas passes through the breathing system it is warmed and humidified by the soda lime. Additionally the integrated heating plate warms the passing gas while reducing condensating water in the system.

hotspot.copy: Breathing Bag For manual ventilation. Allows to assist, control or observe ventilation.
Y-piece Connects inspiratory and expiratory breathing hose with the patients side, e.g. mask or tube. May have optional filters.
Inspiratory and expiratory hoses Transport the gas mixture to and from the patient during ventilation.

APL (Adjustable Pressure Limiting) Valve Limits maximum pressure during manual ventilation and exhausts excess gas into the scavenger system during manual and spontaneous ventilation. On the pressure control valve APL, you can select between manual ventilation Man. and spontaneous breathing Spont.
To adjust settings with the APL (Adjustable Pressure Limiting Valve) Valve, proceed as follows 1. Turn the adjustment knob to switch between manual and spontaneous modes 2. In manual mode rotate clockwise to increase and counterclockwise to decrease pressure 3. Pull up the APL valve to release pressure temporarily
Integrated heater The integrated heater reduces buildup of condensed water, and at the same time supports a better humidification and breathing gas temperature right from the start.

items.item: The E-Vent Plus does not need any kind of driving gas due to it is electronically driven functionality. This reduces costs and allows a longer operation without a central gas supply. In case of an emergency the ventilation can also be performed with ambient air.
E-Vent™ plus Performance
The electrically driven E-Vent™ plus ventilator delivers highest precision and speed as well as a peak flow of 150 L/min.

-<textformat blockindent="33"> Fastest reaction times needed for assisted spontaneous ventilation modes</textformat> -<textformat blockindent="33"> Achieves almost the same performance as an intensive care respirator</textformat>

Expiratory flow controlled ventilator piston return. The ventilator synchronizes itself with and actively supports expiration, which considerably reduces the expiratory resistance and reduces the expiratory resistance
Quick and easy patient change is supported by bodyweight-related presetting of parameters and alarms
Very rapid dynamic compliance compensation and minimal insp. system compliance
Unrestricted applications, including especially pediatric ventilation
Fresh-gas decoupling
assets/global/img/B1170/B1200_2.png
Ventilator Technology
Electrically powered and controlled piston cylinder unit with 2 rolling seals
The vertical movement of the piston transfers the corresponding volume towards the patient (tidal volume: up to 1400 ml)
In Standby mode, the piston returns to the lower end position, ready for the first breath
In Volume mode, the piston moves back by the amount of tidal volume to be delivered
In Pressure and Man/Spont. mode, the piston starts at the lower end position to allow application of any size of tidal volume

items.item: Allows to connect an active or passive scavenger system to remove excess gases.
The anesthetic gas scavenging system (AGS) is intended for the following purposes:
Extracting and removing excess anesthetic gas and expiratory gas
Reducing the concentration of anesthetic agent around anesthetic workstations
Filtering and scavenging contaminated expiratory gases during ventilation
Scavenging sample gases from monitors

The AGS anesthetic gas receiving system operates as an "open system". The excess anesthetic gases/expiration gases are channelled into the buffer container of the receiving system, from where they are exhausted in a continuous volumetric stream via the transfer system into the disposal system. The openings in the receiving system prevent any increase in expiratory pressure or any negative pressure in the breathing system.
assets/global/img/B5110/B5110.jpg

Bar graph for fresh-gas utilization (econometer) (optional)
Parameter field for gas monitoring

items.item: Dräger Anesthesia workstations have the same operational philosophy. The rotary knob is the main operating control of the device and has the following functions in all setting operations:
Select/set = turn Clockwise rotation increases a value, counterclockwise rotation decreases a value.
Confirm = push If the selection is not confirmed, the value or parameter will not change.
assets/global/img/B2120/Bild_1.jpg

An example for a screen layout configuration is displaying the CO2 concentration – Curve display – Numerical display – Trend curve for CO2 Airway pressure – Curve display (PAW) – Numerical display – Bar graph Flow and volume – Curve display flow (insp./exp.) – Numerical display

subsubsite.label: Trendscreen
subsubsite.title: Trendscreen
subsubsite.headline: Trendscreen of the Primus
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: Displays the measured values over an interval beginning with the start of the measurement. Maximum storage time: 8 hours. The following display combinations can be selected: – agents – MV / CPAT / CO2 / O2 – SpO2 pulse (optional)

subsubsite.label: Alarms: Overview
subsubsite.title: Alarms: Overview
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: Alarm messages are displayed in the alarm field in order of priority.
To call up alarm limits during operation: Press the soft key alarm limits.
The curves with the alarm limits represented by dashed lines are displayed on the left.
The current measured values and their alarm limits are grouped in the field next to the curves.

When ventilation settings have been made, Primus can automatically adapt the alarm limits for minute volume MV and the airway pressure PAW to the current parameters in Volume Mode, Volume AF, Pressure Mode, and Pressure Support.

subsubsite.label: Alarms: more than 3 alarms
subsubsite.title: Alarms: more than 3 alarms
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: Up to three messages can be displayed simultaneously. In some cases, the corresponding measured values are highlighted on the screen by a flashing background in addition to the alarm message. If more than three alarms occur simultaneously, the symbol "more" appears to the right of the alarm field.
The soft key "show all alarms" is activated on the right-hand side of the screen to show the hidden alarms.

subsubsite.label: Alarms: Show all alarms
subsubsite.title: Alarms: Show all alarms
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: When the soft key show all alarms is pressed, the upper curve display is replaced by up to six additional alarm fields for 15 seconds. If more than nine alarm messages are simultaneously active, the lowest priority alarms will not be displayed until the total number of active alarm messages falls below nine.

subsite.label: Advanced Monitoring
subsite.title: Advanced Monitoring
subsite.copy: This chapter gives you more detailed information about the option Advanced Monitoring.

items.item: assets/global/img/B3110/Econometer_2.jpg

The bar graph indicates the qualitative utilization of the fresh-gas flow. If the fresh-gas delivery is more than 1 L/min above the gas consumption, the econometer will indicate surplus. Below this level, utilization of the fresh gas is considered efficient. If less fresh gas is delivered than is needed by the patient, a fresh-gas deficit is indicated by the red area in the bar graph and a fresh gas alarm is generated.
The gas consumption depends on: – the patient’s uptake, – leakage, and – the CO2 volume absorbed.
assets/global/img/B3110/Econometer_1.jpg
If data for calculation are not available, the legend appears in gray and the bar graph is not active.

subsubsite.label: Loops
subsubsite.title: Loops
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: To call up the Loop display press the Loop softkey in the standard screen.

The Loop display shows P/V- and V/Flow-Loops. It is used for fast analysis of changes of the patients lung mechanics. Display of: - Memory Loop for assessment of the last 3 breathing strokes - Reference Loop for definement of an benchmark curve

subsite.label: Ventilation Modes
subsite.title: Ventilation Modes
subsite.copy: This chapter gives you more detailed information on the Ventilation Modes.

items.item: Volume controlled ventilation with constant inspiration flow
assets/global/img/B4110/Volume_controlled_ventilation_1.jpg

Intended use: Anesthesia in relaxed or partially relaxed patients with healthy lungs and in patients with cranio-cerebral trauma. The goal is to maintain a constant volume or a constant "etCO2".
Volume-controlled ventilation mode with fixed mandatory tidal volume VT and frequency freq. (former IPPV), as well as with optional synchronization activation (former SIMV(VC)) and variable pressure support for spontaneous breathing efforts (former SIMV(VC)+PS, optional).
The respiratory cycle is defined through the frequency freq., the inspiratory time TINSP, the inspiratory pause time TIP:TINSP and the tidal volume VT.
The Volume controlled mode reaches all patient populations (20 - 1400 ml, f 3 - 100 min-1) without changing components and reduces the inspiratory system compliance and permits correct delivery of set tidal volume from the first breath (compliance compensation).
Synchronization of volume controlled ventilation and spontaneous breathing
assets/global/img/B4110/Volume_controlled_ventilation_2.jpg

Synchronization is activated as soon as a trigger sensitivity value is entered. The message "sync" is displayed in the ventilation mode status field on the screen.
The flow trigger sensitivity controls the synchronization. The maximum time delay between the controlled ventilation breaths is adjusted by means of the frequency. To keep the frequency constant in the event of a premature triggering, the time is equalized in the next ventilation cycle.
A ventilation breath triggered by the patient is indicated by a continuous line in the pressure curve and in the flow curve (trigger indicator). The active flow trigger window corresponds to the last 25% of the relevant expiratory time.
Volume controlled ventilation with AutoFlow
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_1.jpg

Volume AF is a pressure controlled ventilation mode with a guaranteed tidal volume VT and frequency freq. as well as optional synchronization activation and variable pressure support for spontaneous breathing efforts (optional).
Volume AF combines the advantages of pressure controlled and volume controlled ventilation mode. The set tidal volume VT is delivered in a pressure controlled ventilation mode. The inspiratory pressure automatically adapts to the set tidal volume, limited by a maximum pressure PMAX. When starting the ventilation with Volume AF, the first mandatory breath is volume controlled in order to identify the necessary pressure level, if not known from a previous ventilation mode.
Primus automatically adapts the inspiratory pressure to the changing lung condition from breathing cycle to breathing cycle in steps of max. ±3 mbar.
The delivery of tidal volume for one breathing cycle is limited to 130 % of the set tidal volume. If the volume limitation is active, the ventilation pressure for the following breath will be reduced to 75 % of the target pressure, but limited to a maximum of 15 mbar above PEEP
Synchronization of volume controlled ventilation with AutoFlow and spontaneous breathing
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_2.jpg

Synchronization is activated by entering a value for the trigger sensitivity. A mandatory breath triggered by the patient is represented by a continuous vertical black line in the pressure curve and in the flow curve (trigger indicator). The active window for the stroke triggered by the patient corresponds to the last 25 % of the applicable expiratory time.
In Volume AF, the patient can additionally end the inspiratory phase during the last 50 % of the applicable inspiratory time when synchronization is activated. An inspiratory phase ended by the patient is represented by a continuous vertical black line in the pressure curve and in the flow curve (trigger indicator).
Iteration process
Cpat known from previous ventilation mode: 1st stroke: Pinsp = VT / Cpat ->target pressure is set First stroke already delivers set VT with pressure mode pattern!
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_3.jpg
Cpat not known from previous ventilation mode: 1st stroke: volume mode breath -> VT 2nd stroke: Pinsp = VT / Cpat ->target pressure is set
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_4.jpg
Changing the VT setting from 300ml to 420ml.
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_5.jpg
Increasing volume: the pressure increases in max. 3 mbar steps Decreasing volume: the pressure directly decreases according to Pinsp new = VT new / VT old * Pinsp old
Change due to the compliance
assets/global/img/B4120/Auto_Flow_6.jpg
When compliance changes in volume mode Auto Flow, Pinsp changes so that VT stays constant (in pressure mode Pinsp is constant and VT, MV changes).
Pressure controlled ventilation with decelerating Flow
assets/global/img/B4130/Pressure_CV_1.jpg

Intended Use: Anesthesia in patients suffering from a lung disease (inhomogeneous lung), neonates, children mask ventilation, pulmonary fistulae, laryngeal masks, inversed ratio ventilation, in relaxed or partially relaxed patients.
Pressure-controlled ventilation with fixed pressure limit "Pinsp" and frequency "1/freq". Synchronization and adjustable pressure support of spontaneous breaths (optional) are switchable.
A continuous flow is applied to the patient during the inspiratory time "Tinsp". The curve's rate of rise can be preset with the slope increase time "TSlope". The maximum time delay between the controlled ventilation breaths is adjusted by means of the frequency. To keep the frequency constant in the event of a premature triggering, the time is equalized in the next cycle.
Changes to the lung compliance and the ventilation parameters affect the tidal volume.
Synchronization of pressure-controlled ventilation and spontaneous breathing
assets/global/img/B4130/Pressure_CV_2.jpg

Synchronization is activated as soon as a trigger value is entered.
The message "sync" is displayed in the ventilation mode status field on the screen.
The flow trigger sensitivity controls the synchronization.
A breath triggered by the patient is indicated by a continuous line in the pressure curve and in the flow curve (trigger indicator). The active flow trigger window corresponds to the last 25% of the relevant expiratory time.
Using this ventilation mode allows reduced interaction with the anesthesia system during recovery and enables a smooth transition from controlled ventilation to spontaneous breathing. The adjustable flow trigger reduces the work of breathing during the spontaneous breathing phases.
Pressure Support of spontaneous breathing
assets/global/img/B4140/Advanced_monitoring_1.JPG

Intended use: Anesthesia in spontaneously breathing patients with laryngeal masks during surgeries without muscle relaxants.
Pressure support for spontaneous breathing can be used in all mechanical ventilation modes. At the same time, this option is an independent ventilation mode. The patient's spontaneous breathing effort is supported by the following factors:
– The flow trigger sensitivity controls the synchronization. – The adjusted pressure setting is a measure of the pressure support.
The curve's rate of rise can be preset with the slope increase time "Tslope".
In addition, an apnea ventilation can be set via the minimum frequency "Freqmin".
If the patient does not breathe spontaneously, the ventilator is activated automatically dependent on the set minimum frequency "Freqmin". The subsequent ventilation breath is not a mandatory ventilation breath. The patient can always stop the mandatory ventilation breath by his/her own breathing activity.
assets/global/img/B4140/Advanced_monitoring_2.JPG

ΔPPS = 0, 1, 2 hPa adjustable in Pressure Support mode.
At same time, min. frequency is deactivated (and re-activated when increasing ΔPPS above 2 hPa).
With each breath of the patient the set CPAP value is maintained.
Synchronization of controlled ventilation and Pressure Support of spontaneous breathing
assets/global/img/B4140/Advanced_monitoring_4.JPG

Pressure support is activated if, during controlled ventilation, a value is entered for the level of the pressure support "Δpps".
The message "PressSupp" is displayed in the ventilation mode status field on the screen. The flow trigger sensitivity and the "Δpps" level control the synchronization or the pressure support.
The maximum time delay between the controlled ventilation breaths is adjusted by means of the frequency. To keep the frequency constant in the event of a premature triggering, the time is equalized in the next cycle.
If, at the time of pressure support activation, the patient was being ventilated without synchronization, automatic activation of the synchronization is initiated with the last trigger setting used.
If pressure support is deactivated with "OFF", the synchronization is maintained with the set value. If the trigger is deactivated with "OFF", then the pressure support will be deactivated automatically.

subsubsite.label: HLM
subsubsite.title: HLM
subsubsite.copy: Please move your mouse pointer over the device or over the text next to the picture. The relevant area will be highlighted.

hotspot.copy: The HLM mode permits patient monitoring without unnecessary alarms during extra-corporal oxygenation of the patient by a heart lung machine (HLM). In the HLM mode: – All gas concentrations are measured independently of the breathing phase – CO2 apnea and pressure apnea alarms are inactive – SpO2 monitoring alarms are inactive. The HLM mode can be used in all active ventilation modes

equivalent isotropic radiated power" of the adjacent RF transmitter

Percentage gas rate in relation to total gas volume
Conformité Européenne Directive 93/42/EEC on Medical Products
Suppress alarm tone for 2 minutes, change priority of technical alarms and acknowledge them
Call up basic screens in succession
Non-rebreathing system at the external fresh-gas outlet
Upper and lower alarm limit disabled

Exit menu, return to preceding menu
Remaining battery capacity (uninterruptible power supply UPS)

items.item:
The following program is solely intended for use as a supplementary training tool. It is not replacing an offical in-service. In the simulation mode the bar graphs and the measured values are similar to the real bar graphs and values. Changing the settings causes the same effects as in real life, e.g. exceeding an alarm limit will trigger an alarm.
The philosophy of using the simulation is the same as in live operation, the principal of "Touch-Turn-Confirm". - Choice of a key: click with the left mouse button on the key - Settings: turn the rotary knob with clicked left mouse button - Confirm: click on the rotary knob

subsite.label: Simulation
subsite.title: Simulation
subsite.copy: Please click on the start-button to open the Simulation. To end this simulation, please click "Close" in the upper right-hand corner of the screen. You will return to the main menu.

Any use of the device requires full understanding and strict observation of the corresponding Instructions for Use. The user must be familiar with the device according to the national and local laws and recommendations. Successful completion of this training program does not imply that the participant has a complete working knowledge of the device as it is the institution’s responsibility to determine the technical aptitude of the user. Furthermore, any practitioner participating in this training program is expected to exercise his or her professional judgement and experience, and to utilize all (including reading all device manuals) training and expertise while operating the device and in dealing with their patients.
